prs.l: in rapid speech especially in sense 2

dt: used as a conventional title of courtesy except when usage requires the substitution of a title of rank or an honorific or professional title before a man's surname
used in direct address as a conventional title of respect before a man's title of office

dt.t: May I ask one more question, {it}Mr.{/it} President?

dt: used before the name of a place, profession, or activity or before an epithet (such as {it}clever{/it}) to form a title applied to a male viewed as representative of the thing indicated

et: {it}Mr.{/it} from Middle English, abbreviation of {it}maister{/it} master; {it}Messrs.{/it} abbreviation of {it}Messieurs{/it}, from French, plural of {it}Monsieur{/it}
shortdef: —used as a conventional title of courtesy except when usage requires the substitution of a title of rank or an honorific or professional title before a man's surname
—used in direct address as a conventional title of respect before a man's title of office
—used before the name of a place, profession, or activity or before an epithet (such as clever) to form a title applied to a male viewed as representative of the thing indicated

dt: {bc}a man who would make the perfect husband

shortdef: a man who would make the perfect husband

dt: {bc}the leader of a group of criminals

shortdef: a very powerful or important man; especially : the leader of a group of criminals

dt: {bc}a man who treats people kindly {bc}a nice man
used chiefly in the phrase {phrase}no more Mr. Nice Guy{/phrase}

dt.t: I'm tired of the way they treat me. From now on, {it}no more Mr. Nice Guy{/it}!

shortdef: a man who treats people kindly : a nice man —used chiefly in the phrase no more Mr. Nice Guy
